Expectation1: Ensuring financial stability for the family
Situation1: The child has been promised a Nintendo, and the mother should purchase it
Expectation2: Communicate any challenges or concerns promptly to the mentor.
Situation2: A technical hurdle is preventing the mentee from advancing on the current project.
Story:
I sat at the kitchen table, my laptop open but my mind elsewhere. My son’s hopeful eyes flashed in my memory—he’d been counting down the days until I could buy him the Nintendo I’d promised. He’d been so patient, and I wanted to keep my word, to see his face light up. But the numbers in my bank account told a different story. Every dollar mattered, and I needed to be careful, to keep us secure.

At the same time, my phone buzzed with a message from my mentor, asking for an update on my project. I’d hit a technical wall days ago, but I hadn’t said anything yet. I worried she’d think I wasn’t capable, that I was falling behind. I knew I should reach out, admit I was stuck, but I hesitated. I didn’t want to seem weak or distracted, especially when I was already stretched thin.

The weight of both roles pressed on me—my son’s trust, my mentor’s expectations. I stared at the screen, torn between the needs of my family and the demands of my career, unsure which voice to answer first.
